William Alfred Ismay or Bill Ismay  (10 April 1910 – 13 January 2001) was a librarian, writer and collector in Wakefield, West Yorkshire known for his significant collection of post-war studio pottery. The collection called the W.A. Ismay Collection was bequeathed to the Yorkshire Museum and is one of the world's largest collections of 20th-century studio pottery. It includes work by Bernard Leach, Hans Coper, Shoji Hamada, Takeshi Yasuda, David Leach Dan Arbeid and Lucie Rie.

After his time in Europe, Azaz returned to Israel to take up the position of head of the ceramic art department at Harsa[In Hebrew] in Beersheba. Joined by young and enthusiastic artists such as Dan Arbeid, he designed and made sculptural pottery artworks influenced by the contours,  shapes and colours of the desert, and also designed pieces that were made and decorated by others. The idea of Maskit was to enable émigré  craftspeople to adapt their skills and Azaz was instrumental in their training and encouragement.
